page.description: Generate a static HTML version of your UX component. Several different files will be generated (e.g. .html, .css, .js, etc.). The collection of files is referred to as a 'fileset'. You must save the component that you want to convert to HTML before you can use this feature.

item.name: Component alias
item.description: Specify an alias for this component. The alias is used to generate the object name for the component at runtime.

item.name: Folder
item.description: Specify the folder where the files should be generated. The files will be generated inside a sub-folder in this folder. If you select the <Webroot> the files will be generated in a folder in your Alpha Anywhere webroot and you will be able to do a Remote Preview on a mobile device or Live Preview in your browser.

item.name: Name
item.description: Specify the name for this fileset. The generated files are placed in a sub-folder with this name inside a specified 'Folder'

item.name: Additional assets to include in Fileset
item.description: Specify the filenames of any additional files in the Web Project that you want to include in the fileset.

item.name: Create application manifest
item.description: Specify if an application manifest file should be created.

item.name: Show manifest
item.description: Specify if the manifest should be shown after it has been created. This will allow you to apply manual edits to the list in the manifest.

item.name: Manifest filter rules
item.description: You can define rules to automatically filter out certain files from the manifest.

description.p: The URL for any ajax callbacks that are made from the page. This property needs to be specified if the static page will be used in a Cordova mobile application or downloaded from a service such as Amazon S3. This is because the application server's URL cannot be inferred from the page's location. In the case of mobile apps, the page is loaded from the device file system. In the case of Amazon S3 or other file hosting service, the Application Server is not used to retrieve the page.

If the static page is used in a web application where the request is made to the Application Server to retrieve the page, the application server can be determined from the page request and you do not need to specify the URL for Ajax callbacks.
Should modified files be overwritten without a warning?
Select this option to generate a Progressive Web App (PWA). Once selected the PWA Settings menu appears.

item.name: App name
item.description: Specify the app name.

item.name: Short name
item.description: Specify the short app name.

item.name: Description
item.description: The description should explain what your app does.

item.name: Static cache name
item.description: The cache name must be unique for each PWA that you publish. If the browser detects a duplicate cache name for different apps, then the required JavaScript service worker will not be installed. By convention use pwa_cache_appname (no spaces allowed, they will be replaced by the _ character).

item.name: Static cache version
item.description: Enter the version number for the static app cache. By convention use v-##.##. Each time any of the files already in the cache are modified (cached files are older, stale) the version number should be changed to invalidate the older cache.

item.name: Dynamic cache name
item.description: The dynamic cache name must be unique for each PWA that you publish. If the browser detects a duplicate cache name for different apps, then the required JavaScript service worker will not be installed. By convention use pwa_cache_appname (no spaces allowed, they will be replaced by the _ character).

item.name: Dynamic cache version
item.description: Enter the version number for the dynamic cache. By convention use v-##.##. If any of the files in the dynamic cache are stale, change the version number to invalidate the older cache. The older dynanmic cache will then be deleted and a new dynamic cache is created. The dynamic cache will then be populated with newer files as they are requested when online.

item.name: Dynamic cache max size limit
item.description: Enter a number (10 to 250) that represents the maximum number of items allowed in the dynamic cache. When the maximum number is reached, the oldest items in the cache are deleted to make room for newer items. A large cache size consumes more resources and can slow app performance.

item.name: Start URL
item.description: Enter the starting URL. Typically ./index.html

item.name: Offline HTML page
item.description: When the device is offline and the html page is not in the static or dynamic cache, this page will be displayed. It is automatically stored in the static cache.

item.name: Master icon
item.description: The app master icon. The file size should be 512px x 512px for best results.

item.name: Display
item.description: How would you like the app to display when launched from the home screen icon? Options include fullscreen,standalone,minimal-ui and browser.

item.name: Theme color
item.description: The theme color determines that top border color when run as a standalone app.

item.name: Background color
item.description: The background color is used as the splash screen when the app is launched. It should be similar to the app background color.

item.name: Using Firebase Cloud Firestore
item.description: Are you using Firebase Cloud Firestore with this app? If this option is checked then the data returned from Firestore requests are not cached in the dynamic cache. This ensures that the data is not stale.

item.name: Hosting with GitHub Pages
item.description: Will you be deploying this web app to GitHub Pages?

item.name: Set noJekyll flag
item.description: (only shown when Hosting with GitHub Pages is checked) In most cases, this flag should be set (checked) if you are deploying the app to GitHub Pages

item.name: Show debug console messages
item.description: When enabled, console debug messages will be displayed. This is typically enabled during the app development phase and turned off when ready to deploy.

item.name: Upload files to Amazon S3 storage
item.description: You can upload the files in the fileset to a bucket in Amazon S3 storage.

item.name: Storage connection string
item.description: To define a storage connection string go to the 'Tools' menu in the Web Projects Control Panel.

item.name: Sub-folder name in Amazon S3 storage
item.description: Specify the folder within Amazon S3 storage that you want to store the static html file

section.title: Create a static HTML version of a Component.

step.description: Create a component and save it.
On the UX Builder's UX Controls page click the 'Menu' dropdown in the toolbar and select the 'Create static HTML files' option.
In the Static HTML UX Generator dialog's 'Location' section's 'Folder' property specify where you want to store the file
Click the [...] button next to the 'Name' property and give the Static HTML a name. Click OK.
Minimize Alpha Anywhere and open your computers file manager. Navigate to the folder where you saved the Static HTML version of you component.
Click on the index page to open static version of the component in a browser.
